recipientOrganization.name: Home-Start York
recipientOrganization.description: We offer early intervention by identifying and providing effective early support to families and their children who are at risk of poor outcomes. Home-Start York recruit and train volunteers. Our team of 42 active volunteers have all attended our 40-hour preparation training course. The training programme covers various topics including parenting skills, safeguarding, signposting, mental health, budgeting and other household management skills. Our volunteers receive ongoing supervision and training. All of our staff and team of volunteers are trained in safeguarding procedures. Once trained, volunteers are carefully assigned a family who they visit each week in their own homes for 2-3 hours. We aim to safeguard, protect and preserve good health, both mental and physical of parents and their children. To prevent cruelty to or maltreatment of children. To relieve sickness, poverty and need among parents and their children. To promote the education of the public in better standards of childcare. After over 30 years of Home-Start York's services in the city, we play an integral part as statutory services continue to withdraw services. With the recent pandemic, we feel it is now essential that we secure further funding so that we can continue to meet the needs of the families in York who need to access early intervention help remotely.

We have identified that many residents in a rural location can feel isolated and vulnerable and we have to strive to provide assistance and support by offering a range of support services. Our work helps our residents and volunteers break isolation and make lasting friendships, access services and the practical help they need or take up one to one support to address barriers that stop them fully engaging in community life. We provide a community hub as a focal point for local services where people can obtain information, advice, support and help. Developing, coordinating and managing local volunteers to operate and develop improved local services by stimulating involvement in local action. Operating and maintain community transport using volunteer drivers, for residents who are not able to access public or private transport. Operating a community library and library delivery service to support the residents in Nidderdale and Washburn and involving the community in its further development to meet local needs.

recipientOrganization.name: Tang Hall Community Centre
recipientOrganization.description: Tang Hall Community Centre sits amid one of the UK's 10% most deprived areas and serve 9,250 residents. Typically, as a community venue, we aim to address social isolation, poverty and health inequality through the help, advice, support and information we provide. We hire our spaces to a number of social enterprises and organisations and let rooms to third parties who hold a wide range of classes, clinics, courses and events. From our Friday breakfast clubs to our food co-operative, as well as fundamental education around growing and cooking healthy food, we encourage residents’ to improve their diet at low cost, which has lasting health benefits, whilst also encouraging social interaction and imparting skills that residents can build on to gain employment, for example. During the coronavirus pendemic, however, we will not be running any classes or workshops, but acting solely as a government Community Hub, delivering advice, support, food and medicine to our those in need within our local community whilst adhering to cleanliness/health rules and social distancing practices.

recipientOrganization.name: Community Integration and Advocacy Centre (CIAC)
recipientOrganization.description: CIAC charitable objectives are:- To advance education and relieve financial hardship amongst Emerging Communities in the Humber Region through the provision of legal and other advice and by any other means as the trustees may determine (Emerging communities are defined as refugees, asylum seekers, EEA migrants and other migrants) CIAC Mission: Supporting emerging communities to contribute fully to life in the UK as committed and active citizens. CIAC provides very low cost, ethical immigration advice to people with recourse to public funds and the right to work underpinning pro bono (free) immigration advice to people without recourse to public funds and the right to work as a long term, sustainable route out of destitution. Our multi-ethnic team of nine volunteers from eight different countries receive training and experience which enhances their future career prospects. Immigration applications such as travel documents, citizenship, lost/replacement BRPs and EU Settled Status are completed by the volunteers under supervision. More complex applications, such as further asylum submissions, lodging appeals, domestic violence applications and family reunions are completed by the CEO/Principal Immigration Advisor. Generalist advice is also provided in our weekly drop in (currently on hold). During the Coronavirus crisis income from fee paying services are expected to reduce yet the demand for pro bono services will increase. In addition, CIAC is bringing together a Local Advisory Group structuring a Well-Being Service offering counselling and therapeutic activities to asylum seekers, refugees and migrants.

recipientOrganization.name: Aspire
recipientOrganization.description: Aspire Oxford supports people facing multiple challenges to find employment and housing. We work with people who have a background of homelessness, offending histories, addiction or mental health difficulties. We provide support that is focused on the needs of each individual, helping them to move forward with their lives. Our support includes work experience on our enterprise businesses, access to training and adult education, homelessness prevention support, housing projects for rough sleepers and ex-offenders, sports and social activities and access to paid jobs with inclusive employers. Last year we supported over 2,000 people in Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire. Aspire is a founder member of Oxford Homeless Movement and runs a range of programmes designed to prevent and tackle homelessness. We run a homelessness prevention programme which gives people the skills, confidence, knowledge and connections to prevent their own homelessness. We run Housing First projects in collaboration with local housing associations. In all of Aspire's programmes, we ensure that people with lived experience are involved at every stage, including co-designing the projects that we run and in 2019 helped to establish Oxfordshire's first Lived Experience Forum.

recipientOrganization.name: Edge Housing - Oxford Community Church
recipientOrganization.description: Edge Housing works with those who have been homeless or vulnerably housed and seeks to support, signpost and mentor these residents into careers which will give them the stability to enter the private rented sector. We have two five bedroom houses and have an investor looking to purchase us a third. We support and challenge our residents to become all they want to be and lead successful lives. We have a team of volunteers who befriend and mentor the residents separately to encourage and listen and simply be a friend. We keep costs low so that when the resident gain employment we can subsidise the rent for three months to allow them to save. We work with Oxford University for careers, all the local support organisations and city councils in providing an individual approach in a home environment where we allow our residents to explore their own lives and we come alongside them. We are a Christian organisation and follow the biblical principle that we are all make for a purpose but we do not evangelise and our residents can be of any or no faith.

recipientOrganization.name: The Porch
recipientOrganization.description: We are a Christian based organisation whose mission is to help in a totally non-discriminatory way, homeless, recently re-housed homeless or vulnerably housed people. We encourage our service users (our members) to tackle the multiple disadvantages that prevent them from moving forwards towards a more positive lifestyle. We concentrate upon housing, companionship, learning skills, work related skills and opportunities for development. We offer a unique day centre based on two elements: one is the basic facilities (a café, a shower/laundry room, free internet access and a library). The other is the support side: we offer one-to-one support addressing the issues of housing, health, education, employment, and wellbeing. We seek to promote a sense of self-worth and purpose, and offer support and challenge to our members in the areas of: • Health -- access to medical/dental services and to the range of health care services we all need • Housing -- help to live where they need to • Education -- to develop their skills and abilities • Employment -- to lead a purposeful life

recipientOrganization.name: On Your Bike (Recycle) Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: On Your Bike (Recycle) Ltd is a local charity that delivers training and work placements for vulnerable and disadvantaged individuals, giving them the skills and confidence to access pathways to employment in Taunton and Bridgwater. It achieves this by recycling unwanted bikes and selling them back into the local community: a process delivered by our trainees (supported by our professional mechanics) in work placements which combine training in bike mechanics, retail, office administration and premises management experience. Figures from the year to March 2018 saw 48 people benefit from one of our work placements. This equates to nearly 4,700 hours invested in support and training for those volunteers and beneficiaries. 16 of those (33%) entered paid employment or left to pursue further training/volunteering. 5 (10%) left with no ongoing plan, 1 (2%) left without informing us of their intentions. 26 (54%) continued their placement with us. During the year to FYE Feb 2018 we sold 651 bikes and serviced approximately 952 bikes for people in our community.

grants.title: COVID19 24 hour advice line for people facing a life limiting illness and their carers
grants.description: COVID19 24 hour advice line for people facing a life limiting illness and their carers

recipientOrganization.name: St Margaret's Hospice
recipientOrganization.description: - Providing hospice care for Somerset St Margaret’s Hospice Care provides high-quality responsive care for families in Somerset when someone is given a diagnosis of a life-limiting illness. We have a vision of a community in which all dying people and those close to them have access to appropriate care and support, when they need it, wherever they need it and whoever they are. Our aim is to bring quality of life to patients and their families, carers and friends so that they can make each day count. Across Somerset we offer a range of services: • Our Community Teams provide care and support in the familiar environment of a patient’s own homes. The community teams provide care for over 260 patients at any one time. • Our 24 hour referral and advice line receives an average of 786 calls per month from patients and carers who need advice from a palliative care nurse and health professionals wishing to make a referral. • Our Sunflower Centre Day Services welcomes attendees who are well enough to live at home but who want to take advantage of our specialist care available through the day. The Sunflower Centre also provides respite for carers. • Our In-patient Unit in Taunton offers patients with complex care needs comfortable surroundings where they receive extra support, symptom control and pain management from specialist teams. • Our Outpatients Services provide a wide range of therapies including Lymphodema Treatment, Physiotherapy, Complementary Therapies, Occupational Therapy, and Psychotherapy. • Our Bereavement Services supports families and carers who have lost a loved one to a life-limiting illness. Our Family Support Worker is specially trained to help children and young people cope with the loss of a parent. • Our support groups offer an opportunity for people to meet with people going through a similar experience. Our carer support services come alongside those caring for their loved ones who have a life-limiting illness. • Our Spiritual Care Team work closely alongside clinical teams to ensure we are caring for patients’ spiritual needs alongside their physical and emotional needs. - Adapting to meet future care needs With over 5,500 people dying in Somerset each year and an estimated 4,000+ people who would benefit from hospice care, we know that there is a growing gap between those we can help and those we are currently unable to reach or support adequately. Over the last couple of years, St Margaret’s has therefore been rethinking how we can improve our reach across the county, address a current national shortfall in medical staffing and respond to patient choice by extending our care within the community, enabling patients to receive end-of-life care closer to home – while all the time ensuring that we remain financially sustainable. The Board of Trustees have recently confirmed that St Margaret’s will increase our work in the community. Providing end of life care closer to home, while ensuring specialist care is available for those who need it across Somerset, are key components of St Margaret’s strategy. This focus enables our teams to support patients and families in the community in a more proactive way, being able to plan care in advance with patients in their own homes about what their future needs might be. We will increasingly work alongside NHS and adult social care community teams to anticipate and prepare for the changing needs that our patients may have. In-patient services will remain a key component of St Margaret’s and we will bring beds together on one site in Taunton, to reduce the ongoing challenge of maintaining sustainable medical staffing with appropriate skills. Our own patients tell us they would prefer to be at home and we want to make sure this can be achieved. However, we understand that this can put an incredible amount of pressure on carers and families. By extending our community provision we can help support other healthcare providers, families and carers to meet the wishes of the patient while feeling safe and supported. St Margaret’s Hospice Care’s strategy is to further increase this in the coming years. Alongside this we are also developing work to encourage early referrals to the hospice. Often people come to the hospice later on in their illness. However, if we can provide opportunities for people with a life-limiting illness to access hospice care earlier we will be able direct them towards activities and support which will assist in improving the quality of their life. This will enable them to remain in control in their home environment, adapting as their health needs change. - Are you sitting comfortably? We would like the Active Living Programme to consider supporting us so that we can offer something new to our patients. The aim of our project is to provide staff and volunteers with the skills to integrate seated exercise into the services currently provided by the Hospice. We believe that this will improve patient's physical and mental wellbeing. By training our staff and volunteers we will have an ongoing and sustainable resource to benefit patients beyond the period of the grant. The seated exercise programmes will be integrated into our existing day hospice provision to enhance the care and subsequent benefits of the service to patients. St Margaret’s Hospice is one charity for the people of Somerset, caring and supporting patients and their families and carers. This new focus will ensure that the charity is in the best possible shape to continue providing high quality, responsive care for more people facing a life-limiting illness across Somerset in the months, and years, to come.

recipientOrganization.description: In Charley's Memory currently offers counselling to young people aged 11 -25, at their office in Burnham on Sea. grants.title: COVID19 Support for expectant and new parents in Somerset
grants.description: COVID19 Support for expectant and new parents in Somerset

recipientOrganization.name: Nourish
recipientOrganization.description: The aims of Nourish - Bumps, Babies and Breastfeeding are to protect, promote and support breastfeeding within the community of Bridgwater and the surrounding villages. Nourish provides a weekly support group, held in Cannington, offering pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers the opportunity to seek support, information and empathy in a non-clinical environment for a small donation. Up until January 2018 the group had been funded by NCT (National Childbirth Trust) and was called NCT Cannington Bumps, Babes and Breastfeeding group. Unfortunately due to funding constraints facing the charity, the NCT could not continue to financially support the group. Thus the breast feeding counsellor leading the service and a handful of passionate and dedicated breastfeeding peer supporters decided to establish the group Nourish to enable the continuation of pregnancy, baby and breastfeeding support service. Support and information about breastfeeding is provided within Nourish by a qualified Breastfeeding Counsellor and trained Breastfeeding Peer Supporters. Women are often referred to the group by midwives and health visitors requiring specific support for breastfeeding, whilst others find the group from publicity such as Facebook, flyers or word of mouth. The group aims to provide a warm, friendly, open environment where women feel safe and secure to express their emotions and seek support to enable them to have a positive breastfeeding experience. As Nourish is free from the constraints of a clinical setting and the pressures on health professionals, we are able to give mothers unlimited time, to listen and offer mother-led support. This enables families to make informed decisions and have a positive experience with breastfeeding. Although Nourish offers support and information about breastfeeding a mother does not need to have an issue directly relating to breastfeeding to attend. All too often a mother needs the emotional support of other mothers to ward off feelings of isolation, anxiety or to simply discuss their trials and tribulations of parenthood whilst establishing friendships. In this way the group positively supports not only breastfeeding but the varied and sometimes challenging experiences of parenting. The group welcomes older siblings attending with their mother so that mothers with subsequent children are included within our reach. Toys and activities are provided to entertain older sibling so that their mother can spend time talking to other mums or seeking support from the peer supporters or breastfeeding counsellor. Refreshments such as tea, coffee and cake help a mother feel relaxed and welcome as well as providing much needed calories to meet the demands of nourishing her baby. We positively welcome the attendance of partners/husband alongside their breastfeeding partner/wife as women who have support to breastfeed from family members feel empowered to continue their breastfeeding journey when faced with challenges. Overall the group's aim is to nourish women, both physically and emotionally, to enable them to have a positive breastfeeding experience.

grants.description: COVID19 Coordination of local volunteers and targeted support for vulnerable groups

recipientOrganization.name: North Taunton Partnership
recipientOrganization.description: THE CHARITY'S OBJECTS ARE TO PROMOTE CHARITABLE PURPOSES FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COMMUNITY IN NORTH TAUNTON AND IN PARTICULAR THE ADVANCEMENT OF EDUCATION, THE PROMOTION OF HEALTH AND THE RELIEF OF POVERTY, SICKNESS AND DISTRESS. We support all residents of North Taunton that are in need, this is done through the community centre offering a morning drop in where we host free confidential advice sessions from organisations such as the Police, SW&T housing and benefits, Citizens Advice and Inspired to Achieved employment support. We provide a morning drop in for residents to enjoy a cup of tea or coffee with friends which is a valuable facility to some of our most lonely and isolated residents, many say they don't know what they would do without it. Afternoons, evenings and weekends we offer various social, fitness and educational classes and activities. although our main service users are the elderly we also provide a programme of activities aimed at younger residents and their families in North Taunton, this takes the form of activity days on a local park in the school holidays, the activity days are now in their 12th year and are very much led by the young people and what they want rather than what we feel they need.

recipientOrganization.name: The Willow Set Preschool and Sun Up Sun Down Club
recipientOrganization.description: The Willow Set Preschool and Sun Up, Sun Down Club is located in Stoke St Gregory approximately 12 miles fromTaunton, Bridgwater, Langport and Street. It is a rural village that includes families from a wide range of backgrounds including the farming industry, Clarks, Hinkley Point and of course willow growing businesses. The setting opened approximately 35 years ago in the church rooms and is now, after hard work and fundraising, situated on the primary school site. We are a committee run preschool with charity status also offering wrap around care. I have managed and run the preschool and wrap around care setting for over 22 years. The wrap around club has only been open just over 5 years and is growing as the need from working parents increases. My aim is to continue to provide outstanding facilities to nurture the children aged 2-11 yrs and provide a rich safe environment with outstanding inside and outside facilities. We also now run a holiday club which has highlighted an obvious need in the community as many of the days over the last six weeks have been at capacity, we again offer outstanding experiences for children to grow and have fun. The project will enable us to offer more for all the children who attend all our 3 settings. I also organise an annual free play evening every for every child, especially as we have families with some diverse needs. Each child will comes with an adult , this has numerous positives as I want parents/carers involved in all we are doing. Firstly to supervise, thus ensuring safety, but really to engage themselves and have fun with all the children. The ethos of the event is to involve parents and promote social cohesion across preschool, wrap around care and outlying organizations and supporting the understanding that Play refers to a collection of voluntary, intrinsically motivated activities that are usually associated with PLEASURE and enjoyment.Or FUN. This is an outside event providing healthy foods to explore and eat will support those families in need of this help. We have a number of disadvantaged children in the village and outlying areas, therefore this being a free evening makes it available to all regardless of their backgrounds. As a setting we work with other organisations in and around the village as we feel every child is important and deserves the best experiences throughout their childhood.

recipientOrganization.description: Timberscombe Good Neighbours is a group of local people who have come together to offer a service in their community for those in need of help and support. The people who need support may be elderly, disabled, single or young parents, carers, those temporarily in need through illness or anyone who may be isolated within our community. Our scheme is available to help anyone living in the parish of Timberscombe. The scheme is there to help people in need, those who, for whatever reason, are unable to help themselves and have no family or friends available. The scheme is not intended to replace professional care or assistance via Social Services. The help offered by Timberscombe Good Neighbours may include: • Providing transport for appointments, hospital visits or to Day Care facilities • Errands, shopping or collecting prescriptions • Preparing emergency meals • Household tasks or gardening • Visiting or befriending • Letter-writing or form-filling • Helping people after discharge from hospital • Giving carers a break • Reading to partially sighted or blind people • Providing information

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual counselling service for people with mental health needs
grants.description: COVID19 Virtual counselling service for people with mental health needs

recipientOrganization.name: Seed of Hope CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Seed of Hope CIC is a Social Enterprise offering Recovery based Social and Therapeutic Horticulture for people with mental health problems. We are based in The Walled Gardens of Cannington and supported in kind by Bridgwater and Taunton College who provide horticultural expertise and facilities. We currently run one day a week on Tuesdays. Our main sessions provide a six hour day of mixed horticultural activity, a yoga lesson and a Recovery group. The therapeutic horticultural activity is tailored to the varied levels of physical ability in the group. We pace the activity throughout the day and take regular breaks. We use the elements intrinsic to horticulture - Being outdoors in nature, increased light levels, working as part of a team towards a common goal, nurturing living plants and environments, gentle exercise and Hope - to deliver improved mental and physical well-being for our participants. Our yoga sessions are offered as a tool for participants to use in day to day life to aid relaxation and improve physical ability. It also serves as a physical warm up prior to our horticultural activity. The Recovery group is based on the format devised by Dr Abraham Lowe in the 1920s and used for many years by Recovery international. Participants share their experiences, support each other and explore the concepts of Recovery. Participants also have the opportunity to gain a level 1 qualification in Practical Horticultural Skills awarded by City and Guilds and assessed by the college. Seed of Hope CIC has three sources of income1-Trading income - Our main product is our horticultural sessions which are paid for through personal health or social care budgets. We also sell a variety of products both online and through the Walled Gardens of Cannington shop. These include household items and garden planters made from upcycled pallet wood, wildflower seeds (Seeds of Hope) and plants that have been grown by participants. We are also plan on expanding our groups to people with dementia and people experiencing work related stress. 2- Projects - Our projects have three aims- to provide a goal for our participants, to improve community green spaces, and to provide income. Our award winning Spring Orchard project was completed in 2017 and we are currently working on the Cannington Church Gardens of Rest. Our design for this project was a finalist in the Church Times Green Church Awards 2017. 3- Grant income- As a Social enterprise we aim to be less reliant on this source of income than the other two. However at this start-up phase of our development we need grant funding to support us whilst we grow and develop. Seed of Hope CIC is set up as a Social Enterprise as opposed to a charity for two main reasons. We believe that the current dominant systems of service provision in mental health take power away from service users. Power is an important factor in a person's Recovery. Setting up as a charity implies that people with mental health problems require charity to help them rather than having the power to work co-operatively in their Recovery. Secondly being in control of the source of our income and how it is spent allows us to maintain our independence as an organisation. This is important to us because it means we do not have to work in ways which we know don't help people with mental health problems in their Recovery journey. Being a CIC allows us to work as a co operative. Everyone who takes part in Seed of Hope CIC can become a member of the CIC entitling them a vote on company policy and strategy. Our founding principles are enshrined in our articles of association, these are- 8.1 Recovery - Seed of Hope CIC is a Recovery based organisation. 8.2 Mental Health - Seed of Hope CIC is concerned with the mental health of participants. We are not convinced by the scientific evidence and through our own experience, of the existence of Mental Illness. This does not discount an individual’s experience of psychological or emotional distress, or the negative impact of this on a person’s life. 8.3 Pay Equality– Seed of Hope CIC will value the contribution of all employees regardless of seniority in the organisation. Seed of Hope CIC will be a co-operative organisation, and as such will cap the maximum pay of any employee to two and a half times that of the lowest paid employee. 8.4 Membership- Every participant will be offered the opportunity to contribute to the governance of the organisation as a Member as defined in these articles. 8.5 Intrinsic Elements-The main activity of Seed of Hope CIC is Social and Therapeutic Horticulture. The main elements of which are shown through research to provide positive outcomes for the participants. Seed of Hope CIC will also carry out activities that provide some or all of the intrinsic elements for participants. 8.6 Diversity of Income-To maintain the independence of Seed of Hope CIC which may be compromised by a disproportionate reliance on any one stream of income. Income will be sought from all of the following sources-Grants, Trading Income, Payment by Participants, Fundraising Activity, Commissioned Activity. 8.7 Participant Director- It is of paramount importance to Seed of Hope CIC to have a Participant Director on the Management Team. In order for them to carry out their role all reasonable adjustments will be made to the organisations arrangements for meetings of the Management Team. 8.8 Humour- Mental Health problems can be both life limiting and life threatening. There is much sadness and distress involved in the lives of those experiencing mental distress. Seed of Hope CIC will at all times work in a positive hopeful way and this includes the use of humour at all levels of our interactions. The intention of this is to raise spirits, reflect on the irony of situations, maintain and promote hope and mental well being. It is not intended to harass, belittle, distress, discriminate, bully or intimidate.

recipientOrganization.name: Sweet Track Counselling Services & The Friends of Sweet Track Counselling
recipientOrganization.description: The Sweet Track Counselling Agency CIC believes in the wellbeing of the local community and the work we do is designed around two core principles: 1. Provide equality for residents of Glastonbury and its surrounding areas who want support for mental ill health or emotional issues by offering affordable and easy access to therapeutic services. We believe in offering choice for individuals who are on a journey of self-help and exploration, meaning people can work with therapeutic methods that suits them best. Our services currently include low cost counselling, eco-therapy, group and art therapy support. 2. Nurture students by providing practical learning experiences for the next generation of counsellors and therapists who are training for their qualifications. We set the trust up because we saw an increase in people suffering who were not able to get access to professional support for their mental health. This was due to obstacles including long waiting lists, cancellations, long distant treatment, high costs associated to private therapy. The increasing demand for professional therapeutic support has put a significant strain on local services. Our aim is to help alleviate some of the burden experienced by local GP’s, schools, local charities, since they are struggling to support the need for help from people relating to mental health struggles.

recipientOrganization.name: Aldates Community Transformation Initiatives
recipientOrganization.description: ACT exists to provide relief to people in need in Oxford, in particular the homeless and ex-offenders. Committed to working towards a just society that allows those in need to flourish, we seek to understand each person’s unique situation and to work closely and supportively with them to get their lives back on track. We aim to be a community where people who are homeless or recently released from prison receive intensive and bespoke support. This includes: - Weekly outreach to rough sleepers, inviting them to our Monday dinner from which they can begin to access further support - Provision of overnight accommodation through the Oxford Winter Night Shelter - Targeted support for people on release from prison or living in the local bail hostel through our Meet at the Gate project, designed to help minimise return to life on the streets or re-offending - Supported housing in 10 properties - 1:1 mentoring including life skills development and support to access employment In this way, ACT seeks to provide opportunities for people who are homeless or at risk of it to rebuild their lives for the long term – and the consistent, committed support they need to do this successfully.

grants.description: Grant to Youth Enquiry Service (Brixham)

grantProgramme.title: Devon Coronavirus Response and Recovery Fund

recipientOrganization.name: Youth Enquiry Service (Brixham)
recipientOrganization.description: Youth Enquiry Service (YES) provides a drop-in information, advice and support services to young people aged 11 to 25, offering a free, confidential service in a welcoming and friendly environment. This support includes counselling, advocacy, mentoring/befriending with the philosophy of empowering and enabling young people. We believe that the young persons physical, emotional and mental health and social development are paramount and essential to the young persons wellbeing. Peer-led initiatives and group work, as well as face-to-face support are organised in order to offer a comprehensive service for the young people of Brixham and Torbay. Information, advice, guidance and support includes benefits, housing and homelessness, sexual health, employment, legal issues, drugs and alcohol, relationship issues and free counselling through our partnership with Checkpoint (The Children's Society). We are a charity working closely with other agencies and have further partnership agreements with Connexions and the Youth Service. We also offer targeted work with those at risk, identified through Children's Services and the Youth Offending Team on projects such as Youth Achievement Awards and AQA accredited workshops. YES supports several youth led local projects, including Brixham Young Volunteers who aim to break down barriers and build bridges in the local community by hosting events for people of all ages. YES workers and volunteers accompany young people to court, doctors appointments, hospital visits and to emergency housing meetings. We supply food parcels for emergencies, travel warrants, shower and laundry facilities for those in need and work closely with Checkpoint to support homeless young people across Torbay.

grants.description: COVID19 Emergency foodbank funding

recipientOrganization.name: The Salvation Army Shepton Mallet
recipientOrganization.description: The Salvation Army is a missional church that looks to provide relevant services in the Community that it works within. In Shepton Mallet we provide many varied services from children's activities to work with the homeless. Our weekly programme consists of two parent and toddler groups, a community drop in with a job club. A digital link club offering both internet access to look and apply for employment, help to provide support with basic computing knowledge, and helping people understand IT when apply for benefits and pay bill's. We also run a Community lunch club which is attended by people who are either looking to get out of the house for a bit of company, people dependant on alcohol and other substances or in some cases for people who don't have enough money to buy food. We also run a club for older people in our community that meets once a week providing them with a place to come and chat with each and share in the activities that we put on. A Brass band for children from the age of 9 upwards. Once a month on a Saturday we run a family craft activity with a cooked meal, to encourage the whole family to spend time together. We have a Charity Shop attached to our building which offers us are only real source of income, and also allows us to be open throughout the week to meet the needs of our community. One of the biggest parts of our work in the community though is the running of the local food bank. over the last twelve months we have given away over 400 food parcels providing food for families or individuals when they cant afford it. The food bank is run on a referral basis and we work closely with agencies, both professional and voluntary, so that we are not just simply handing out food but helping to deal with the underlying need of why the service users do not have enough money to buy it. Along side the food bank we run a Christmas appeal. Again this takes referrals from agenesis of families who without help for what ever reason could not have afforded Christmas. We do around seventy Christmas food hampers and provide toys for over one hundred and fifty children.

As of 1st April 2014 the Charity became a Charitable Incorporated Organisation, and the trustees changed the name to Tendring Eldercare as it kept more in line with the services we provide. With over 30 years of experience the aims of the Charity are to improve the quality of life for older people. Particularly those who are isolated many of which are living in the rural areas of Tendring, to reduce isolation and alleviate the pressure on their families and carers. grants.title: Grant to Accuro (Care Services)
grants.description: to respond to the COVID19 crisis and help sustain an organisation which supports children, young people and adults with a learning disability and their families in West Essex

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

recipientOrganization.name: Accuro (Care Services)
recipientOrganization.description: Accuro is a small, local charity, which aims to support people with learning disabilities in Harlow and across West Essex by delivering a wide range of social activities to avoid loneliness and social isolation and to provide much needed respite to families. Accuro • develop potential of people of all ages with learning disabilities, • help teach new skills including life, social, communication skills • help avoid loneliness and social isolation • improve self-confidence, self-esteem • increase independence • increase happiness, wellbeing • help prepare children for adulthood • provide respite for families Accuro’s strategic vision is to eliminate loneliness and social isolation of people with learning disabilities within their local communities, enhancing their confidence to cross bridges into a wider world. Accuro currently run the following services to meet our aims • Cool connections – a youth club for children U19 with Autism (ASD) in Harlow • Under 19 project – 2 youth clubs for children U19 with disability, in Uttlesford (Great Dunmow and Saffron Walden) • Loughton Youth Group – for U19s in Loughton • Saturday Play club – U16s in Saffron Walden • School Holiday Project – Group activities and 1 to 1 sessions across Harlow, Epping and Uttlesford. • Adult Friendship Scheme – Social Evenings, small group activities in Harlow and Uttlesford By working closely with our service users, their families and community partners such as Essex County Council we ensure we identify the need and develop innovative creative solutions to meet the identified need, enhancing the lives of local children, young people and adults with disability and their families. Accuro provide opportunities for local people with disability to belong, contribute and thrive. We have over 35 years’ experience and a proven track record of delivery. We make a real impact and in our 2016 stakeholder survey 100% of respondents said they were “proud of Accuro” and would “recommend us to a family in need.” Respondents in our stakeholder survey also told us “Accuro is a lifeline” and “Without Accuro my sons’ life would be less”. We were told Accuro have “given my child a chance” and “are a highly valued support for our family and have helped us cope in the darkest of times when we felt alone” “My son gets so much from Accuro”, “my daughter has made most of her friends at Accuro” and “we couldn’t get the support from anywhere else, the whole family benefits from the break”. A volunteer said, “I have never been happier than when I was able to volunteer every week – it was honestly the highlight of my week.” A grant from HRF will help Accuro continue to make a real difference to the lives of local people with disability, and their families / carers in Harlow. The funding from Harlow recreational fund will enable us to continue to provide social and recreational activities for people with disability living in Harlow attending Cool connections and / or Harlow Adult Friendship scheme. Accuro provide opportunities for local people to belong, contribute and thrive and with your support we can continue doing so. Thank you for considering our application.

recipientOrganization.name: Wilderness Foundation UK
recipientOrganization.description: The Wilderness Foundation reaches in the region of 5,500 children, young people and adults per year. We prepare and educate participants for the future through participation and inclusion in wild activities. We promote that nature and wild spaces are of incalculable value not just to maintain biodiversity and wildlife but for human wellbeing. Our objectives as set out in the memorandum of association are: *To advance the education of the public by increasing knowledge and understanding of wilderness and the conservation thereof, the interrelationship between wilderness and the environment generally by the provision of instruction, and of opportunities, for direct experience of wilderness. *To initiate and manage social benefit programmes which will use wilderness experience to enable vulnerable and disadvantaged people to play a fuller role in society (especially the young). All our projects and programmes provide direct support, connecting people to nature for wellbeing benefits, mental, spiritual and physical – and to teach people in turn to care for nature into the future. We teach Leave no Trace Ethics, respect for, and understanding of our impact on the web of life whilst developing positive social connections and relationships.

recipientOrganization.name: Welcome to the UK
recipientOrganization.description: Welcome to the UK supports migrant families in Southend to engage in our community, realise and reach their aspirations. We enable families to adapt to life in the UK, including language barriers, personal and professional development and isolation. We work annually with 150 women and their families from 20 countries. In 2012, our founder moved to the UK, unable to speak or understand English. She will not forget how hard everything was. She had started a new life, in a new country, expecting her first child. She looked for an organization, to reduce the loneliness she felt. Online she found nothing local. She joined ESOL and in 2014 started her own friendship group for migrant mothers. We remain the only group of its kind locally, and have all-female trustees with experience of migration. We hold friendship groups with women and their children, English classes and other workshops. Our activities are driven by peer-to-peer support built between members. We enable migrant women to overcome barriers in achieving their self-defined aspirations. Our work supports families, to feel safe, and secure, whilst also enabling them to feel pride in Southend as their home by encouraging them to be actively involved in their communities.

grants.title: Grant to First Stop Centre
grants.description: to sustain an organisation supporting vulnerable people in Braintree during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: First Stop Centre
recipientOrganization.description: First Stop Centre is a community drop in centre, based near the town centre in Braintree. Our mission is to work with people who are disadvantaged, in a non-judgemental way in order to improve their lives. We have been operating in Braintree since 1981 and over that time we have worked with other agencies and hundreds of clients. We see a wide range of clients including: Those who have a history of mental health Those who have learning disabilities Substance mis-users The homeless Single Parents Unemployed Ex-offenders Senior citizens We offer many interventions in order to make a difference, these are: Basic Skills education classes (English, Maths and Computer Classes) Life Skills training (anger management, self-esteem building, budgeting skills) Individual Time Limited Counselling Benefits advice Job seeking skills (C.V. construction and interview techniques) Advocacy Service (within the context of citizen advocacy) Canteen Befriending Many of the clients that access First Stop are people that have slipped through the net. Some are unable to read and write, many are not engaging with other statutory agencies. Because we are a small independent charity, we are able to work with these clients and in many cases provide the support in order that they can access the help they need. We provide the clients with a positive experience, which gives them the best chance of making changes in and to their lives and moving forward. Each week we see over 50 clients. The difference we made to these clients included: Many were able to engage in classes and work towards a formal qualification. Some clients were able to produce a C.V. and to link this to internet job sites, where appropriate Clients who attended our anger management classes have reported they have been able to start making more positive choices about their behaviour We helped clients towards social inclusion and become less socially isolated Provided a safe meeting place for other interventions from other agencies- as we are known to many of their clients and they feel safe meeting here We pride ourselves on being non-judgmental and working to enable the client, for some this is over a short period of time, for others this may take a lot longer, and the forming of a trusting relationship with us is a huge step for some. We are able to take steps at the client’s pace, and we often feel like parents gently pushing the clients to make positive choices and steps towards becoming a more active, healthy member of our community.

grants.title: Grant to Community 360
grants.description: for the costs of a community response project during the COVID19 pandemic to provide support for the most vulnerable people in Braintree, Colchester and Maldon

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Community 360
recipientOrganization.description: Community360 (C360) is an independent charity formed in 1968. We are committed to a vision to build “thriving local communities”. Our Mission is: - “To inspire and enable local community action to improve quality of life”. We aim to do this in line with our core values, which are to: - provide passionate, intelligent leadership for the sector in Colchester, Essex and beyond; - empower people, groups and organisations through high quality support - -be creative and innovative in meeting the needs of local communities and the voluntary and community groups and organisations that serve them; and - be fair and honest in everything we do We achieve this through a number of projects, including an experienced Community Development team, Community Accounts Service and Business Bank. As a result, staff lead on community volunteering programmes with more than 400 volunteers, work with over 300 community groups a year to access funding, embed good financial practices, recruit their own volunteers, plan and train, as well as network and promote what they do. We value working in partnership and consult regularly with the sector to guide the development of policy, co-produce new projects and deliver services. We also manage programmes that provide fundamental, practical support to the community. Our Community Transport schemes facilitate over 50,000 trips each year and we hire scooters and wheelchairs to people 5 days a week. Our organisation is constantly evolving, anticipating opportunities in our community and seeking to maximise the impact that we can all have to make our vision a reality. As the provider of Community Voluntary Services (CVS) for Braintree District, we deliver projects that improve the quality of life for local residents and enable voluntary action to impact in neighborhoods and parishes. At the heart of what we do is Community Development. We support charities and non-profit making groups to form, establish their activities and continue to operate, whilst upholding good standards of practice. We help them to find the resources they need (i.e. funds or in kind donations), network and collaborate to enhance their opportunities (such as through Lunch and Learn sessions) and to learn and develop with the provision of courses and bespoke training. We are involved in many fora and committees to work well across the voluntary and community sector. We identify gaps and develop services to meet them. For example, we have established the Braintree District Older Persons forum, where agencies that support older people can network and work together on shared agendas to support older residents in the district. We manage Braintree Time Bank – we encourage social action through the principles co-production, time bank members use time as currency to exchange skills and support. Over the past year 57 new time bank members have exchanged 2000 hours of time to support the local community through initiatives such as a Community Caretakers scheme and i-tea computing sessions. We oversee Braintree Volunteer Centre – as 1 of 14 centres in the Volunteer Essex network we advertise and recruit volunteers for 200 organisations as well as provide guidance and support around volunteer management and best practice. We have placed 69 volunteers in the first six months of the year. We are introducing a Slipper Exchange as part of our falls prevention agenda. Braintree residents can exchange old, sloppy and worn slipper for a new well fitted pair as well as find out information on support services and community activities. We have already exchanged 45 pairs with plans to expand this during the Winter period. We also have a strong commitment to health and wellbeing initiatives, which we would like to continue to expand. We embed good health and wellbeing throughout all of our programmes. However, we seek to offer targeted support where possible. This may be through volunteering, our community weight management service, providing social groups or monthly Tree-Mendous walks of Braintree and Bocking Gardens. Throughout Mid Essex we work with a range of partners and have particular strong working synergies with Braintree District Council as part of the Live Well Child campaign (addressing childhood obesity and working with ten schools in the district), Active Braintree Network and the Strategic Health and Wellbeing Board. We pride ourselves on providing proactive community engagement, meaning we like to take our services to people. Working throughout the district we understand the challenges faced by town and rural communities, particularly with regards to accessing services. We are adept at working with residents to establish activities based on their needs, rather than prescribing a ‘one size fits all approach’.

grants.title: Grant to Citizens Advice Bureau - Colchester
grants.description: for new IT and telephone systems to enable volunteers and staff to work remotely during the COVID19 pandemic

grantProgramme.title: Essex Coronavirus Response and Recovery Programme

grants.Impact Category: Maximise ability to strengthen community cohesion and build social capacity

recipientOrganization.name: Citizens Advice Bureau - Colchester
recipientOrganization.description: CAC was established in 1939 as one of the original 200 Citizens Advice bureaux opened by the National Council of Social Services. From its inception, the service has been volunteer-led and existed to provide free, confidential, impartial advice to the citizens of Colchester to help them with the problems they face. The aims of CAC are to: • Provide free confidential and impartial advice and information for the benefit of the local community • To influence the development of social policies and services • To ensure that individuals do not suffer through lack of knowledge or inability to express their needs effectively. These aims contribute to the reduction of crime and antisocial behavior as: • We help clients escaspe from the cycle of long term debt, enabling them to return to economic activity. Last year we helped clients write off nmore that £600,000 of debt • We help clients to claim the benefits they are entitled to. Last year, we helped claim £64,000 of additional benefits • We help clients understand their rights and responsibilities at tenants. Lasr year, we helped with 3,000 housing issues • Help clients resolve employment issues. Last year, we helped with 1,200 employment issues To achieve these aims, we provide: • Face-to-face advice 5 mornings per week from our Crouch St Office (drop in service) • Follow-up appointments 5 days per week for more complex cases (casework) • Telephone advice 5 afternoons per week • Email advice 5 days per week via the Colchester Advice Network (CAN) • Face-to-face advice for 5 sessions per week at Colchester Central Library • Face-to-face advice on Wednesdays at Wivenhoe library (enabling library opening on a day when it would otherwise be closed). In addition, we run discrete projects to provide: • 1 session of face-to-face advice at the Lakes Mental Health unit, with follow-up casework where needed • 5 days specialist debt advice for Colchester Borough Homes tenants via home visits with follow up specialist casework. • 5 days advice via webchat • Weekly evening advice session at the Military Corrective Training Centre (MCTC) with follow up specialist casework. • Financial Assessment Benefits Advice (FABA). • Home Visiting Service for Essex County Council (ECC) benefits service. (Referral basis) In total, CAC provided advice to 12,000 clients last year (discrete client contacts) with 16,350 separate issues*. A bulk of advice (42%) related to debt, followed by benefits and tax credits (18%) and employment (10%). We monitor client volumes on a quarterly basis to ensure client contacts are in line with target. We also monitor trends in the mix of issues to ensure the skills of our advisers matches emerging client needs. * These figures include telephone and webchat advice. Some client contacts via these channels will be from outside the borough.

recipientOrganization.name: Cholsey Day Centre Trust
recipientOrganization.description: Cholsey Day Centre Trust runs a day centre for up to 35 members three times a week, and is open to the elderly, those with mild to moderate impairment issues, and mild to moderate dementia. As well as a cooked meal at lunchtime the Day Centre offers an increasingly diverse range of activities and entertainments, as well as providing a limited range of outreach provision.

grants.title: COVID-19 Responding Positively
grants.description: We are closed and therefore not receiving the weekly attendance fees from members. Our major fundraiser , the Easter bazaar has had to be cancelled .We are continuing to fully employ our Coordinator to maintain at least regular weekly contact with members ( by phone , letter and e mail) and their family many of whom live away and in any case cannot visit.

recipientOrganization.name: The Wychwoods Day Centre Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: We are a locally based Day Centre for the Elderly with 22 members(average age 85) We meet once a week offering refreshments and a two course home cooked lunch with activities ranging from music therapy to church services, scrabble to quizzes. Our aim is to reduce social isolation and enable people to remain at home for as long as possible .We are the only type of provision of its kind in the Wychwood Villages and apart from a part time paid Coordinator exist entirely through the efforts of approximately 50 volunteers who drive, help and cook.

grants.title: COVID-19 Creatively Clever
grants.description: We are setting up a programme of online and at home resources for young people aged 13-19. We will provide bespoke tutorials and any equpiment needed to access them in topics of interest to young people. We will also be providing virtual youth club spaces hosted by qualified youth workers to support young people facing disadvantage and dealing with pressure created by the pandemic.

recipientOrganization.name: Leys CDI
recipientOrganization.description: Leys CDI is a local charity which develops and co-ordinates projects of long-term benefit to the Blackbird Leys and Greater Leys estates in Oxford. It is a grass roots project that is led by local people and focuses on delivering a project for young people aged 9-25 and an over 50's project called The Clockhouse. The organisations strengths lie in its community roots and its trusted relationships with local people who are at the heart of the organisation. Leys CDI strongly believes in enabling local people to get involved and learn new skills and progress through the project to leadership.

grants.title: COVID-19 MLMC Coronavirus Service
grants.description: Following Government advice and to ensure the health and safety of our members with a learning disability and our staff and volunteers, we have taken the decision to close our office and put all of our activities, projects and group work on hold. In order to secure the financial sustainability of the charity we have cut all unnecessary costs and taken advantage of the Government’s Staff Retention Scheme. However, we recognise that during this crisis, the physical and mental health of our members is at risk due to the loneliness, isolation, worry, confusion, and in some cases lack of support that they will experience.

recipientOrganization.name: Oxfordshire My Life My Choice Association
recipientOrganization.description: Our mission is threefold: 1. To make sure that there is independent support for people with learning disabilities in Oxfordshire to have their say, claim their rights and to take control of their own lives. 2. To make sure that the views of people with learning disabilities are taken seriously by both professionals in the services they use and the wider public. 3. To “Power Up” their lives so they can make a positive contribution to society. Our activities include a peer-led travel training scheme, user-led training, a learning disability nightclub, Gig Buddies, a campaigns team and 13 self-advocacy groups.

grants.title: COVID-19 Kirtlington Youth Club Survival
grants.description: We have shut down our club night and our youth leader is staying in contact with all our members through social media. He provides puzzles, tasks and challenges to the group whilst at the same time keeping very close contact with our more vunerable members ( bullying being the main issue ). Due to Covis 19 we have lost three very valuable income streams that would have ensured our survival until our main fund raiser in Nov ( ? ).

recipientOrganization.name: Kirtlington Youth Club
recipientOrganization.description: Kirtlington Youth Club caters for the young people of both Kirtlington and the surrounding villages ( Bletchington, Weston on the Green etc, ). We aim to provide a safe and secure enviroment for young people ( age 10-16) in a rural area to meet and overcome some of the restrictions that living in a rural village give young people. We look to integrate the young people into the village community and give them a voice.

grants.title: COVID-19 Emergency Family Support Project
grants.description: Oxfordshire Family Support Network is facing an unprecedented need for support from an incredibly vulnerable demographic. We are currently operating in an adapted way, without face to face contact - but continue to proactively support families. Whilst we are able to quickly adapt, the needs we are seeing dwarf the level of support we have needed to supply in the past.

recipientOrganization.name: Oxfordshire Family Support Network
recipientOrganization.description: Oxfordshire Family Support Network exists to support and empower the family carers of people with learning disabilities. We provide information, advice and 1:1 support - helping carers to self advocate and enabling them to ensure the right support for their family member. The families we work with tend to be caring for a loved one with severe or profound needs, who is unable to live independently. Whilst we work with famiy carers - the adults and children with learning disabilities that they support are our ultiamate beneficiaries.

grants.title: COVID19 Support for new parents in Somerset
grants.description: COVID19 Support for new parents in Somerset

recipientOrganization.name: Carry Me Kate Parenting Services CIC
recipientOrganization.description: We offer support to parents and carers of children. We offer sling and carrier hire and support to allow people ot carry there babies and toddlers, we offer feeding support to parents both breast and bottle. We run groups to allow parents to come out and form part of a community. We also offer parents evidence based information in which they can then make there own parenting choices from evidence based informtion delivered in a appropriate way. Due to corona we are unable to run groups and offer parents the much needed face to face support.

grants.title: COVID19 Meal delivery service for vulnerable people
grants.description: COVID19 Meal delivery service for vulnerable people

recipientOrganization.name: Dulverton Good Neighbours
recipientOrganization.description: Our aim is to "Here to help when you need it".To help our community become more empowered through community self-help volunteering. We step in when friends and family are not around. Many of the businesses are now closed in Dulverton therefore we have seen a three fold increase in the number of people coming forward to volunteer. We did have 20 registered volunteers we now have over 60 and increasing daily. Likewise we have seen an increase in demand for food parcels due to unemployment as well as increased demand for delivery services to our frail and elderly community.

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual support for adults with learning disabilities in Yeovil
grants.description: COVID19 Virtual support for adults with learning disabilities in Yeovil

recipientOrganization.name: The Hub Yeovil Community Support Charity
recipientOrganization.description: Overall aim is to provide support and training to empower the lives of people with learning disabilities and autism, helping each individual achieve their own personal independence, support their community and work together, beyond disability. We have had to close our building which means that our trainees with learning disabilities and autism are not able to use the Hub and its services and the parents/guardians are not receiving the respite whilst the trainees would normally be receiving the day service. We are also facing challenges with cashflow and concerns that our trainees may not return after a long gap.

grants.title: COVID19 Virtual support service for people with mental health needs in Wells
grants.description: COVID19 Virtual support service for people with mental health needs in Wells

recipientOrganization.name: Heads Up
recipientOrganization.description: Heads Up, a Wells based Charity, aims to help adults across Mendip who are affected by mental health issues. Many are affected by enduring conditions such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, anxiety, stress, depression and dementia. Since the coronavirus outbreak and ‘lockdown,’ clients have been unable to access our workshops and courses. As a result we are not receiving payments as we would normally. We have adjusted our service to provide outreach provision including shopping, prescription runs as well as telephone support which can be up to three times a week for some. This all incurs costs: staffing, transport, phones etc.

grants.title: COVID19 Information, advice and entertainment
grants.description: COVID19 Information, advice and entertainment

recipientOrganization.name: Glastonbury FM
recipientOrganization.description: We provide informative services, a wide range of local news, information and topical issues relating to the target communities to enable the better understanding of our communities and links within them. We interview public figures and agencies to provide information to the community. We also provide entertainment in the form of local music. We have closed our doors to our volunteers for their protection. Only 2 local Directors (as Key Workers) access the studio. To maintain a live and current public service broadcast we need equipment and software.

grants.title: COVID19 Stillbirth and neonatal bereavement support in Yeovil
grants.description: COVID19 Stillbirth and neonatal bereavement support in Yeovil

recipientOrganization.name: Sands
recipientOrganization.description: Sands is the UK’s leading baby death charity. 14 babies a day are stillborn or die within 4 weeks of birth in the UK. We exist to: • support anyone affected by the death of a baby for as long as they need us • work with health professionals and the NHS to support bereaved parents and families • fund vital research to stop babies dying Our volunteers in Somerset need support and training to offer vital bereavement support via new platforms as support groups cannot meet.

recipientOrganization.description: we are an active church at the centre of our community, delivering projects and support for all parts of our community, including family support, elderly, homeless, mental health, employment, youth, early years and much more. our challenges and response are quite diverse. moving our family support to virtual support where possible and developing safe practices for where we still need to work in homes, adapting safeguarding around children, young people and vulnerable adults. adjusting our homeless support to the new landscape, providing more space for foodbank expansion, and coordinating volunteer network across yeovil in partnership with SSDC, Spark & yarlington

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Funding to enable the organisation to continue to support members of BAME communities in Hull particularly Iranian but also other ethnicities. Many are refugees and asylum seekers with very limited income, food parcels will be distributed and translation services available to help people understand medical advice.
grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: Iranian Community of Hull (ICOH)
recipientOrganization.description: The Iranian Community of Hull (ICOH) is an Anglo-Iranian voluntary and community group which supports newcomers and facilitates their integration into British society. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS) more than 600 people with Iranian ethnic heritage are living in Hull. Iranians make up the highest proportion of asylum applications to the U.K. and Hull has a disproportionate number of Iranians who have settled in the city. ICOH has around 300 active members. We work in close liaison with leading local charities and Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) community groups based in Hull and Yorkshire to: - Deliver training and employment services. - Support asylum seekers with their relocation. - Provide emotional support and special services. - Run cultural and social activities. Training and social activities are used by ICOH to introduce beneficiaries to British and other minority ethnic customs, reduce loneliness and discourage segregation. We have already seen more members finding employment, gaining confidence speaking English to local people, befriending individuals from outside their ethnic community and an understanding of British customs.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding to enable services to continue.
grants.Impact Category: Advance people's physical and mental health, wellbeing and safety

recipientOrganization.name: JPC Community Farm
recipientOrganization.description: We provide relief to people with complex needs by reason of disability by providing accommodation, care, development opportunities and employability training, as well as through the provision of respite facilities, advice and services for those who care for them. We provide meaningful day care support, specialist education and independence training for disable people, with a focus on young adults. This includes sessions to address their needs and improve their confidence as well as a range of independent living and other transferable skills, including household skills, personal care, accessing community facilities, rights and leisure activities. Most of our beneficiaries face multiple disadvantage including through physical impairments, sensory impairments, autism as well as learning or mental difficulties, meaning they required 24-hour care and support. We also operate The Orangery, an on-site community café as a social enterprise which provides employment and work experience opportunities for our disabled participants. We have also applied for funding to provide a free meals delivery service for vulnerable people during the current Covid-19 pandemic.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19 response. Funding will support organisation increased project costs to enable them to continue to reach participants.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Revival North Yorkshire CIC
recipientOrganization.description: Our objective is to support and improve the mental, physical and emotional well-being of the local community, particularly those who are elderly and vulnerable in the rurally isolated North York Moors. We aim to: • Combat loneliness and isolation • Promote home independence • Revive the culture and heritage of the North York Moors through local traditions and activities We currently provide a range of support, services and activities which encourages community spirit ,bringing people together, so that they can maintain connections and make new friendships which will help to prevent loneliness and isolation. We provide Memory Lane Lunches in the Danby and Sleights areas, Memory Lane Music and Good Old Days reminiscing sessions. We are currently sourcing funding to begin Move It or Lose exercise classes in to villages. We have applied to The National Lottery Community Fund for funding and this will no doubt be seriously delayed in the current situation.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding for fuel and equipment for remote working, and for staff costs to support adults with learning difficulties.
grants.Impact Category: Improve life skills, education, employability and enterprise

recipientOrganization.name: Ripon Community Link
recipientOrganization.description: Ripon Community Link supports adults and young people with learning disabilities offering day services and work experience. We do this at two sites, St Wilfrid's Bungalow, a dedicated facility in the heart of the community and at Ripon Walled Garden a 4 acre site which has a woodland, orchard, historic walled garden and is open to the public. The Bungalow offers a wide range of support learning activities such as literacy, numeracy, art and drama. We also run community based groups such as recycling, rambling, sports and work experience roles at our pop-up coffee morning and community shop in a local residential home. At the Walled Garden service users have the opportunity to learn about horticulture in the gardens and customer service in the Tearoom. Woven through all our work is skill based education, supporting individuals to develop and explore their interests and to develop literacy, numeracy, money management and interpersonal skills. Through this we aim to improve independence and tackle potential issues of loneliness and poor health both mental and physical.

grants.title: Covid19
grants.description: Covid-19. Funding to set up connectivity for vulnerable people with no internet connection.
grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Springbank Community Association
recipientOrganization.description: We have provided all the usual community activities and facilities from our purpose built community centre for over 30 years. For the last ten years we have specialised in delivering help with IT to over 12000 people per year who didnt or hadnt had access to IT or dont have IT literacy through no fault of their own. Last year we delivered a three month pilot project delivering IT help in the home to over 50 elderly or disabled people. We provided help with internet connectivity and various home IT aids eg.Alexa, audio visual door alerts and audio visual connectivity via skype on large screens eg tv screens or tablets. We provided free recycled computers in many cases which had been donated and we had removed all data or installed new hardware in. We provided temporary connectivity via dongles in many cases and delivered instruction in use of all the equipment. The present emergency highlights the vulnerable people who are not connected to internet services. Fair numbers of people still do not have any contact with the outside world apart from ordinary phones and many do not have or can use smart phones. All current advice and information is via the web and these people dont have access to it!.These people will become known as the emergency unfolds and different organisations provide help and assistance outside the doors but there arent organisations set up to help connect them connect. We could provide dongles and tablets with very simple connection instructions.

recipientOrganization.name: Love Driffield
recipientOrganization.description: Love Driffield exists to relieve poverty in the town of Driffield and the surrounding area of the East Riding of Yorkshire. This is primarily through running the Driffield and Wolds Food bank. The objects of the CIO are: To relieve persons in the Driffield and surrounding ares of the East Riding of Yorkshire that are in financial hardship in such ways as the trustees from time to time think fit, in particular, but not exclusively by: a) running a food bank, knows as "The Driffield and Wolds Food bank" providing emergency food, essential toiletries, and household items to individuals and families in need and/or for distribution by charities or other organisations working to prevent or relieve poverty. b) Such other means, including (but not limited to) the provision of support or signposting to relevant information and other advisory services.

recipientOrganization.description: Incredible Edible Marshland aimsto bring together the Marshland villages through growing and sharing, to support a kind, confident and connected community. We currently have a programme of cookery classes, tutored gardening classes, community gardening/growing projects, social activities around cooking/growing/sharing. We have planned a VE Day planting session, a programme of communal growing, developing of verges with wildflowers to support the environment, a 'Clothes Swap' and other activities to support community engagement.

recipientOrganization.description: Paperworks is a charity and social enterprise providing personalised support for individuals with autism, learning disabilities, and complex needs. Our aim is to enable our clients to play a greater part in their communities. We offer the chance to develop in a real work environment with tailored one-to-one training plans, as well as opportunities to meet new people and gain skills in a range of well being activities and projects.

grants.Impact Category: Promote reduction of isolation and disadvantage and access to local services

recipientOrganization.name: Local Works Ltd
recipientOrganization.description: Local Works Ltd was established in 2011 and is an alternative education provider specialising in delivering sports based education programmes. In particular, the company focuses on providing courses for young people who find it difficult to cope with the formal education system, are from deprived backgrounds and who face multiple barriers to personal development. The objective of the programmes offered is to create opportunities for young people to develop their social skills, gain confidence and self-esteem and break out of an often isolated and marginalised existence. The company offers a BTEC course in Active Sports and Leisure and has contracts with local schools and academies to deliver the programme. In addition, the company offers evening activities that are not qualification based but are focused on developing on young people's team skills, learning how to relate to others and understanding their role in the local community. The recently delivered I Will Fund financed project in conjunction with the Two Ridings Foundation was a great success and we have continued to provide for the young people using our resources and a small grant from the Crime Reduction Fund. A small group of 8 volunteers has been formed from the group arising from the young people’s own initiative.We focus on the most vulnerable young people in the local community.

We have obviously closed our cafes and are now providing free food packages with 3 days food including cooked meals to the most vulnerable in Harrogate, Knaresborough & Boroughbridge. We have given food packages to over 250 people in the first 8 days.
